response.answer_text: The answer to this is entirely dependent on a person‘s belief system. There are people who don’t think it’s wrong to steal, or to kill. As a Christian, I believe in the Judeo Christian values from the Scriptures. And by that, I mean that there are real morals, defined in the Scriptures, and then there are others out there who have made up “morals,” or standards of behavior based on their own belief. They believe in moral relativism, I don’t. The problem with moral relativism is that mankind will never agree on what is moral, and many people will indulge in evil acts, and as they killed their moral compass, will justify them as reasonable within some twisted stream of logic. Let me give you an example. In some poor countries, perhaps many, families in a state of poverty with many children might sell their daughters into the sex trade to make money. Because it takes care of the “greater good” of the family, they justify it is OK. My mother worked in Egypt for a couple years. She was surprised to see her young boy missing hands and feet begging for money in the street. A little later she saw another one, and asked her Egyptian contact what was going on? How did it happen? Her Egyptian contact explained that for poor families, while the daughters might be useful to sell into various sexual moneymaking schemes, the boys made more pitiable beggars if the parents cut off their hands and feet. This increased profits to the family and so it was not an entirely rare occurrence. And I hope anyone reading this found it as monstrous as I did. But it is a perfect example of the evils of moral relativism.

Q. What are immoral acts? -Generally, harming (killing) living beings, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying and intoxication are the immoral acts according to Theravada Buddhism, at least. -Specifically, there are ten immoral acts according to Theravada Buddhism. - Not doing the bad things, doing the good things, keeping one’s mind purely- these are the Buddha’s teaching.- Not doing the bad things -The three physically immoral acts. A certain one destroys living things without compassion.He takes what is not given.He misbehaves in sexuality.-The four verbally immoral acts. For his benefit, for another’s benefit, or for some small gain, he would tell lies with awareness.He would slander. Hearing here, he would tell it elsewhere to make a split here. He disunites the united, is fond of telling words to disunite.He would talk roughly, say words that are sharp and cursing, words with anger.He would say frivolous, untimely, untruthful words, words that could not be treasured.The three mentally immoral acts. One wants others’ possessions, wishes may those things be mine.He is angry with a defiled mind, thinks may they come to destruction and not exist.He has wrong, perverted view that there are no results for a gift and sacrifice. There are no results for good and bad actions. There is no this world, no other world, no mother, father, no spontaneously arisen beings and no recluses and Brahmins who have come to the right path and by themselves realizing declare this world and the other world.Source - Tipitaka
